comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: From the British Medical Journal, 27 April 1895, p. 957: "EXAMINING BOARD IN ENGLAND BY THE ROYAL COLLEGES OF PHYSICIANS AND SURGEONS. THE following gentlemen passed the First Examination of the Board in the subjects indicated under the Five Years' regulations: [...] Part IV. Elementary Anatomy. - H. T. D. Ackland, St. Thomas's Hospital;" europepmc.org/articles/PMC2509546/pdf/brmedj08766-0014b.pdf New Zealand Herald, Rōrahi XXXV, Putanga 10933, 12 Hakihea 1898, Page 6 "At the ordinary quarterly comitia of the Royal College of Physicians, held last week, Mr. H. T. F. Ackland, of the University College, New Zealand, and St. Thomas' Hospital, London, was granted a license to practice." paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=NZ... Various NZ and Australian newspapers in August 1917 recorded the award of his CMG: Evening Post, Volume XCIV, Issue 35, 10 August 1917, Page 7 paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP... Grey River Argus , 10 Hereturikōkā 1917, Page 2 paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=GR... Brisbane Courier, 10 August 1917, p 7: trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/page/1594570 He returned to New Zealand on the 20th January 1919, being principal medical officer on the transport "Ruahine." paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=DO...

comment.author: 78249091@N05
comment._content: Te Ara – The Encyclopedia of New Zealand has an extensive biography of Hugh Thomas Dyke Acland who provide medical support during 3 wars www.teara.govt.nz/en/biographies/3a2/acland-hugh-thomas-dyke

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: There is a short entry in Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hugh_Acland_(surgeon) And on the Peerage website: www.thepeerage.com/p3154.htm#i31531 Also, some information on his enlistment from the: Auckland War Memorial Museum Cenotaph database: muse.aucklandmuseum.com/databases/Cenotaph/37093.detail?O...

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: The Dictionary of New Zealand Biography article (cited above) seems to be the fullest account, but there are some additional scraps of information, e.g.: It appears that he played rugby for the St Thomas' Hospital team in 1898: www.forgottenbooks.org/readbook_text/St_Thomass_Hospital_... He wrote a research paper published in the Lancet in 1904: www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(01)49984-3/fulltext doi:10.1016/S0140-6736(01)49984-3 He is also mentioned in a report of a NZ Trained Nurses' Association meeting in 1920: Kai Tiaki : the journal of the nurses of New Zealand, Rōrahi XIII, Putanga 2, Paengawhāwhā 1920, Page 59 paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=KT... He was made Knight Bachelor (Kt) in the King's Birthday Honours (1933): www.nature.com/nature/journal/v131/n3319/abs/131830d0.html
